content.question: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) A block slides back and forth without any appreciable loss of energy on a track with a slight circular curvature, as shown above. The maximum height <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the track at each end is much smaller than <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The center of mass of the block oscillates between <math alttext="x equals negative D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals positive D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The curve is so gradual that the total distance traveled along the curved portion of the track by the center of mass of the block can be considered to be <math alttext="2 D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block undergoes two full oscillations in 8.0 seconds. (a) Which of the graphs above, Graph 1 or Graph 2, could represent the magnitude of the horizontal component of the block’s acceleration as a function of its position on the ramp, and which graph could represent the magnitude of the block’s momentum as a function of its position on the ramp? Justify both your choices with physics principles.

(15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) A block slides back and forth without any appreciable loss of energy on a track with a slight circular curvature, as shown above. The maximum height <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the track at each end is much smaller than <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The center of mass of the block oscillates between <math alttext="x equals negative D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals positive D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The curve is so gradual that the total distance traveled along the curved portion of the track by the center of mass of the block can be considered to be <math alttext="2 D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block undergoes two full oscillations in 8.0 seconds. (a) Which of the graphs above, Graph 1 or Graph 2, could represent the magnitude of the horizontal component of the block’s acceleration as a function of its position on the ramp, and which graph could represent the magnitude of the block’s momentum as a function of its position on the ramp? Justify both your choices with physics principles.

(b) For the system consisting of only the block, describe how the mechanical energy of the system changes, if at all, as the block moves from <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="x equals negative D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer.

(c) Graph 3 above shows the total horizontal distance traveled by the block as a function of time as it completes two oscillations. Using the graph, determine the distance <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the midpoint of the ramp and the maximum position of the block on the ramp. Explain how you arrived at your answer.

(d) Suppose the entire setup was moved to the Moon, where the gravitational field strength is less than that on Earth. The center of mass of the block again oscillates between <math alttext="x equals negative D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals positive D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Would the period of the block’s oscillation on the Moon be greater than, less than, or equal to the period of oscillation on Earth? Justify your answer.

(e) A student derives the following equation for the period <math alttext="uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the block’s oscillation: <math alttext="uppercase T equals, 2 pi times the square root of the fraction with numerator D squared, and denominator 2 H g, end fraction " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>H</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>. Whether or not this equation is correct, is the equation consistent with your answer to part (d)?

(f) Track 2 is identical to Track 1 except there is nonnegligible friction between the block and Track 2. The block is released from rest on Track 2 at position <math alttext="x equals positive D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="lowercase t equals uppercase T sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the block moves to the left, passing through position <math alttext="x equals negative one half D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. After the block reverses direction near <math alttext="x equals negative D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the block moves to the right, passing through position <math alttext="x equals negative one half D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="lowercase t equals uppercase T sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. At which time, <math alttext="uppercase T sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="uppercase T sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, if either, is the magnitude of the tangential acceleration of the block greater? Justify your answer.
